chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of blepharitis
chapter.summary: Covers the management of chronic blepharitis, including when to refer a person with blepharitis.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 12 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage blepharitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If referral is not indicated, advise the person that:
    • Blepharitis is a chronic, intermittent condition which requires ongoing maintenance treatment — cure is generally not possible.
      • Patient information is available from the NHS ‘Blepharitis’ and Association of Optometrists ‘Blepharitis’.
    • Symptoms can usually be controlled with self-care measures such eyelid hygiene and warm compresses.
      • The eyelid can be cleansed by wetting a cloth or cotton bud with cleanser (for example, baby shampoo diluted 1:10 with warm water) and gently wiping along the lid margins to clear any lid debris.
      • Eyelids should be cleaned twice daily initially, then once daily as symptoms improve.
      • In addition, a warm compress (a clean cloth warmed with hot water) should be applied to closed eyelids for 5–10 minutes once or twice daily — compresses should not be too hot as this may burn the skin.
      • Eyelid hygiene should be continued even when symptoms are well controlled to minimise number and severity of relapses.
    • For posterior blepharitis, a brief gentle eyelid massage following the use of a warm compress can help improve expression of Meibomian gland secretions.
      • Care must be taken to prevent mechanical irritation.
      • Pressure on the eye area should be avoided in people with glaucoma.
      • For further information, see the CKS topic on Meibomian cyst (chalazion).
    • Eye make-up (especially eyeliner and mascara) should be avoided.
    • They should seek review if symptoms persist, worsen or new features develop.
  • If there is evidence of an associated condition (such as dry eye syndrome, seborrhoeic dermatitis or rosacea) ensure this is appropriately treated:
    • For further information, see the CKS topics on Dry eye syndrome, Seborrhoeic dermatitis, and Rosacea - acne.
  • If eyelid measures are ineffective:
    • Review the diagnosis and consider the need for referral.
    • Do not prescribe topical steroids.
    • For anterior blepharitis, consider prescribing a topical antibiotic (such as chloramphenicol) to be rubbed into the lid margin.
      • The frequency and duration of topical antibiotic treatment depends on the severity of the blepharitis and response.
      • For prescribing information, see the CKS topic on Conjunctivitis - infective.
    • For posterior blepharitis associated with meibomian gland dysfunction and rosacea consider prescribing oral antibiotics (such as doxycycline [off-label] or tetracycline [contraindicated in pregnancy, lactation and in children under 12 years]).
      • For information on prescribing, see the CKS topic on Rosacea - acne.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of blepharitis are based on the clinical guidelines Blepharitis – Preferred Practice Pattern 2018 [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018] and Blepharitis (lid margin disease) [College of Optometrists, 2018], a Cochrane review Interventions for blepharitis [Lindsley, 2012] and expert opinion in review articles [Benitez-Del-Castillo, 2012; Carlisle, 2015; Duncan, 2015; Putnam, 2016].

Advice
  • Expert opinion in a clinical guideline [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018] and review article [Putnam, 2016] highlight the importance of patient education on the chronic nature of blepharitis and the need for compliance with ongoing treatment (in particular eyelid hygiene) even when blepharitis is well controlled.
  • Advice on avoidance of cosmetics (especially eyeliner and mascara) is based on clinical guidance from the College of Optometrists [College of Optometrists, 2018].
Eyelid hygiene and warm compresses
  • Expert opinion in clinical guidelines [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018; College of Optometrists, 2018] and review articles [Duncan, 2015; Putnam, 2016] is that eyelid hygiene is the mainstay of treatment of blepharitis.
  • Lid cleansing removes bacteria and deposits from lid margins and improves symptoms in most people with blepharitis. High quality evidence on the comparative efficacy of different lid hygiene regimes is lacking [College of Optometrists, 2018].
    • Eyelid cleansing is particularly useful for anterior blepharitis [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018].
    • The optimal dilution factor of baby shampoo with water is unknown, but 1:10 is often recommended as providing a good balance between irritating and cleaning actions.
  • Warm compresses soften adherent scale or discharge and warm meibomian secretions to aid gland expression [Putnam, 2016; American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018; College of Optometrists, 2018].
    • Warm compresses, in addition to eyelid cleansing with lid massage, may be particularly helpful in management of posterior blepharitis and meibomian gland dysfunction (MDG) [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018].
    • Expression of the meibomian glands through lid massage must be performed with care — manipulation of the eyelid can cause mechanically induced irritation [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018].
    • People with glaucoma should be advised to avoid putting pressure on the lids as this may subsequently increase eye pressure [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018].
Optimal management of associated conditions
  • Blepharitis is associated with a number of other conditions (such as dry eye syndrome, seborrhoeic dermatitis and rosacea) which may share common aetiologies and predisposing factors. Recognition and appropriate treatment of underlying conditions is recommended in clinical guidance [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018] and a review article [Putnam, 2016].
Topical corticosteroids
  • A Cochrane review [Lindsley, 2012] looking at interventions for chronic blepharitis found that evidence of effectiveness of topical steroids was inconclusive. In addition, corticosteroids may have significant adverse effects and should only be initiated by an ophthalmologist in secondary care [British Oculoplastic Surgery Society, 2014].
Topical antibiotics
  • The recommendation that topical antibiotics can be considered as second line treatment in people with anterior blepharitis if lid measures have failed is based on expert opinion in clinical guidelines [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018; College of Optometrists, 2018] and review articles [Carlisle, 2015; Duncan, 2015; Putnam, 2016]. The recommendation on use of chloramphenicol is taken from clinical guidance from the College of Optometrists [College of Optometrists, 2018].
  • A Cochrane review (n=34 studies [26 randomised controlled trials and 8 quasi‐randomized controlled trials]) including 2169 people with blepharitis (1661 with anterior or mixed blepharitis and 508 with posterior blepharitis) found that [Lindsley, 2012]:
    • Topical antibiotics provided some symptomatic relief and were effective in eradicating bacteria from the eyelid margin for anterior blepharitis — there was no difference between the types of topical antibiotics used.
    • Lid hygiene may provide symptomatic relief for anterior and posterior blepharitis.
  • Clinical guidelines [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018; College of Optometrists, 2018] do not give a specific timescale for use of topical antibiotics and recommend that frequency and duration of treatment is guided by the severity of blepharitis and response to treatment
    • A review article [Putnam, 2016] states that topical antibiotics are commonly continued for 4-8 weeks depending on severity.
Oral antibiotics
  • The recommendation that oral antibiotics can be considered as second line treatment in people with posterior blepharitis and meibomian gland dysfunction if lid hygiene measures have failed is based on expert opinion in clinical guidelines [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018; College of Optometrists, 2018] and review articles [Carlisle, 2015; Duncan, 2015; Putnam, 2016]. Evidence on the effectiveness of oral antibiotics for blepharitis has been shown to be inconclusive.
  • A Cochrane review (n=34 studies [26 randomised controlled trials and 8 quasi‐randomized controlled trials]) including 2169 people with blepharitis (1661 people with anterior or mixed blepharitis and 508 with posterior blepharitis) found that [Lindsley, 2012]:
    • Evidence for the effectiveness of oral antibiotics was inconclusive.
    • Lid hygiene may provide symptomatic relief for anterior and posterior blepharitis.
  • The recommendation by the American Association of Ophthalmology on use of oral antibiotics in people with MGD if eyelid cleansing/meibomian gland expression has failed is based in part on small clinical trials which found that oral tetracyclines improved symptoms in people with rosacea and MGD [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with blepharitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer for same-day ophthalmological assessment if:
    • There are symptoms of corneal disease (such as pain and blurred vision).
    • The person has experienced rapid onset visual loss.
    • Orbital or pre-septal cellulitis is suspected, or
    • An eye becomes painful and/or red — for more information, see the CKS topic on Red eye.
  • Refer to ophthalmology (with urgency depending on the clinical situation) if:
    • There is eyelid asymmetry or deformity (to exclude malignancy).
    • There is a gradual deterioration of vision.
    • An underlying condition (such as Sjögren's syndrome or ocular pemphigoid) is suspected.
    • Treatment in primary care has failed — have a low threshold for referring children.
    • The diagnosis is uncertain.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to refer a person with blepharitis are based on the clinical guidelines Blepharitis – Preferred Practice Pattern 2018 [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018] and Blepharitis (lid margin disease) [College of Optometrists, 2018] and expert opinion in a review article [Carlisle, 2015].

  • Malignancy (such as basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma, or sebaceous carcinoma) should be considered if blepharitis is unilateral or associated with loss of eyelashes, a nodular mass, ulceration, scarring, yellow conjunctival nodules, marked inflammation or is non-responsive to treatment [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018].
  • Autoimmune disease (such as ocular mucous membrane pemphigoid) may present with conjunctival scarring and deformity of the lids [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018].
  • The recommendation on having a low threshold for referring children with blepharitis is based on guidance from the American Academy of Opthalmolgy guideline [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018] which states that the risk of serious complications, although rare, is higher in children [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2018].
